awd_titl_txt: Brain network biomarkers of plasticity in aging
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Adam Gazzaley at the University of California, San Francisco, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist examining the neural mechanisms that predict cognitive and brain plasticity in older adults. Cognitive control comprises a set of neural processes that are critical for goal-directed behavior. Non-pathological declines in cognitive control functions are common in healthy older populations, such as pronounced distractibility during working memory performance. There have also been numerous efforts to develop non-invasive methods to enhance cognition in aging, such as cognitive training interventions. However, there is typically heterogeneity in the magnitude of cognitive and neural plasticity across older adults, both in terms of cognitive abilities and training outcomes. The proposed research seeks to identify neural predictors of these individual differences in plasticity in healthy older adults. This work provides important advances in our understanding of the neural mechanisms of cognitive declines in aging and, importantly, offers methods to ameliorate declines in an optimal, personalized manner. 
  
The proposed research uses fMRI, functional connectivity, and cognitive training to identify neural predictors of individual differences in plasticity in older adults. The project builds on previous lines of work by examining the predictive relationship between brain network properties and (1) short-term plasticity as assessed during cognitive control tasks that tap aspects of selective attention and working memory and (2) long-term plasticity as assessed by training-related cognitive gains. The central hypothesis of this project is that cognitive and neural plasticity in older adults can be predicted by aspects of brain network organization, in particular brain network modularity, a metric that quantifies the degree to which brain regions belonging to the same sub-network are more connected to each other than the rest of the network. The expected outcomes of this research plan are significant because they contribute to our understanding of the neuroscience of cognitive plasticity and, importantly, how these functions can be improved in older adults. More broadly, the outcomes of this proposal further our mechanistic understanding of how properties of large-scale brain networks support complex behaviors. It is anticipated that the outcomes of this proposal serve as a foundation to develop targeted, personalized interventions to enhance cognitive control in older populations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cognitive control (CC) functions, such as attention, working memory, and multi-tasking, are a set of processes that are critical for goal-directed behavior. Non-pathological CC declines are common in older populations, and further, these declines are exacerbated by the presence of distracting information. Despite the presence of such age-related cognitive declines in older adults, there have been numerous efforts to develop non-invasive methods to enhance CC in aging, such as cognitive training interventions. Although these interventions have shown some promise to enhance CC and improve distractibility in aging, there is typically inter-individual variability in the magnitude of (1) distractibility difficulties and (2) training-related improvements in cognition. The major aim of this proposal was to identify neural biomarkers of such individual variability. Achieving this aim would allow us to use neural markers to better understand variability in cognitive difficulties in older adults, as well as their improvements with cognitive interventions.

For our first aim, we used functional MRI (fMRI) to examine how brain network properties predict behavioral distractibility during a working memory task in a sample of older adults (N = 17, aged 62-81 years old). Measures of brain networks are key organizing principles of the brain, where we can quantify how different groups of brain regions (or networks) are connected (or ?communicate?) with one another at the whole-brain level. We found that older adults who had greater connectivity within key task-related networks (e.g., the visual network and the so-called ?default mode? network) exhibited greater distractibility. Further, interactions between these networks and CC-related attention networks were most predictive of distractibility. These results suggest that visual and default-mode networks are likely a source of "suppression signals? for processing distracting information, and that lower connectivity between these and CC-related attention networks yields greater distractibility in older adults.

For our second aim, we examined how neural biomarkers predict CC improvements in two populations of older adults who underwent two different forms of training, a multi-tasking training and a digital meditation training (N = 20 and 23, respectively). In both groups, we found that older adults with higher alpha power, measured with EEG, prior to the intervention at ?baseline? exhibited the greatest training-related CC improvements. These results suggest that alpha power, a key metric of attention and learning during training, can predict intervention success. Ongoing work is examining differential predictors of training outcomes to ultimately personalize training interventions (e.g., predict which individual will benefit most from a particular intervention).

The outcomes of this research have contributed to our understanding of how neural biomarkers predict individual differences in CC-related declines in aging, as well as their improvements with interventions. We believe that understanding biomarkers of age-related CC declines and offering methods to improve these processes will help to address a critical societal concern related to our aging population, given that the ability to successfully employ CC functions has significant real-world consequences in older adults, such as the capacity for performing independent living abilities. Moreover, we anticipate that the prediction framework used here will provide methods to identify individuals who have CC deficits and would benefit from cognitive interventions. Finally, we anticipate that the outcomes of this proposal will result in innovative approaches for the personalization of interventions to enhance cognition in older adults in future research.
